page.title: 12Penshaw Monument
page.content: The{Monument}crowns Penshaw Hill and overlooks the village. It is a copy of the Greek Temple of Theseus and was built, with stone from local quarries, in 1842. It was built in memory of the fist Earl of Durham, John George Lambton, who died in 1840. It was paid for by local people and 10,000 people watched the foundation stone being laid. It is now owned by{The National {Trust}and is a famous landmark which can be seen from over 15 miles away on a clear day. It has 18 hollow columns one of which contains an unsafe staircase. Every pillar is 35ft high. It is 100ft long and 53ft wide. It is a popular viewing point and picnicing spot for local people and at Easter it is the custom to roll paste eggs down the hill. (Paste eggs are hard boiled eggs).
